titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Queens County Surrogate's Office summonses 1977.597
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-18 19:21:09 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Two 1816 summonses from the Queens County Surrogate's Office relating to the estates of George Van Alst and Nathaniel Tyler.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Queens County Surrogate's Office summonses, 1977.597, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level. This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two handwritten copies of a summons delivered to Martinus Van Alst of Fishkill, N.Y. instructing him to appear before the Surrogate's Office in Queens County, N.Y. for matters pertaining to the administration of the estate of George Van Alst, and the bottom portion of a summons from the Queens County Surrogate's Office to an unidentified individual regarding the administration of the estate of Nathaniel Tyler. Documents date from 1816.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The material in this collection is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
